ground_truth: Laurie comes back downstairs, takes a key out of her purse, and steps to the window, then to the front door, putting the key to the Doyle house in her pocket. She locks the Doyle house and walks away into the street. The camera moves toward the Wallace house, which is dark and ominous. The wind whips her clothes and hair as she moves down the street, shivering in the chill wind. Bob's car sits on the street. She picks up her speed, moving up the sidewalk as the house looms closer. The camera moves to the front of the Wallace house as Laurie walks up to the front porch, knocks on the door, and rings the doorbell. She stands there, listening for any sound from inside, and waits a moment. Laurie thinks and looks to the street, then steps off the porch and walks to the side of the house, the camera tracking with her. She turns and walks through the breezeway between the house and garage to the back door, pulls it open, and steps into the house, standing there for a moment staring into the blackness of the dark kitchen. Laurie searches for the wall light and looks again into the darkness. A sound from upstairs, like dragging across the floor, stops abruptly. Laurie moves to the head of the staircase and slowly starts up, with the camera tracking her ascent. As she reaches the top and stops, she sees the bedroom door at the end of the hall with faint orange light around its edges. She moves toward the door, the camera tracking with her, and reaches it. The door swings open to reveal a Jack-O-Lantern casting an eerie glow around the room. Someone is lying on the bed, but Laurie can't see them from her position. She moves forward and sees Annie on the bed, with her face a chalky white and a huge red gash across her throat. Laurie stares and screams at the top of her lungs, jumping back to the door. Strung up to the light fixture on the ceiling is Bob, eyes open and staring, causing Laurie to shrink back into a dark corner. Suddenly, a door next to her slowly opens to reveal Lynda standing there, propped up by a chair, staring with glazed, dead eyes. Laurie backs out of the bedroom, her mouth open in speechless horror.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Laurie returns back downstairs, takes a key out of her handbag, and steps to the window, then to the front door, putting the key to the Doyle residence in her pocket. She secures the Doyle dwelling and walks away into the avenue. The camera progresses toward the Wallace residence, which is dim and foreboding. The wind lashes her garments and hair as she moves down the thoroughfare, trembling in the cold breeze. Bob's automobile sits on the street. She picks up her pace, moving up the walkway as the house looms nearer. The camera advances to the front of the Wallace home as Laurie walks up to the front porch, knocks on the door, and rings the chime. She stands there, listening for any noise from inside, and waits a moment. Laurie contemplates and looks to the street, then steps off the porch and walks to the side of the dwelling, the camera tracking with her. She turns and walks through the breezeway between the abode and garage to the back door, pulls it open, and steps into the house, standing there for a moment staring into the blackness of the dim kitchen. Laurie searches for the wall light and looks again into the obscurity. A noise from upstairs, like dragging across the flooring, stops suddenly. Laurie moves to the head of the staircase and slowly starts up, with the camera tracking her ascent. As she reaches the top and stops, she sees the bedroom door at the end of the corridor with faint orange light around its periphery. She moves toward the door, the camera tracking with her, and reaches it. The door swings open to reveal a Jack-O-Lantern casting an eerie luminescence around the room. Someone is lying on the bed, but Laurie can't see them from her location. She moves forward and sees Annie on the bed, with her face a chalky white and a huge red gash across her throat. Laurie stares and screams at the top of her lungs, jumping back to the door. Strung up to the light fixture on the ceiling is Bob, eyes open and staring, causing Laurie to shrink back into a shadowy corner. Suddenly, a door next to her slowly opens to reveal Lynda standing there, propped up by a chair, staring with glazed, lifeless eyes. Laurie backs out of the bedroom, her mouth open in speechless terror.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Laurie is brought back downstairs, a key is taken out of her purse by her, and the window is stepped to, then the front door is approached, the key to the Doyle house being put in her pocket. The Doyle house is locked by her, and the street is walked into. The camera is moved toward the Wallace house, which is made dark and ominous by its appearance. Her clothes and hair are whipped by the wind as the street is moved down by her, shivering in the chill wind. Bob's car is seen sitting on the street. Her speed is picked up, and the sidewalk is moved up as the house looms closer. The camera is moved to the front of the Wallace house as Laurie approaches the front porch, knocks on the door, and rings the doorbell. There she stands, listening for any sound from inside, and a moment is waited. Laurie thinks and her gaze is directed to the street, then the porch is stepped off, and the side of the house is walked to by her, the camera tracking her movement. She turns and the breezeway between the house and garage is walked through by her to the back door, which is pulled open, and the house is stepped into, there standing for a moment staring into the blackness of the dark kitchen. The wall light is searched for by Laurie and the darkness is looked into again. A sound like dragging across the floor is heard from upstairs, and it stops abruptly. Laurie, with the camera tracking her ascent, moves to the head of the staircase and slowly starts up. As the top is reached and she stops, the bedroom door at the end of the hall is seen by her with faint orange light around its edges. Toward the door she moves, the camera tracking with her, and it is reached by her. The door swings open, revealing a Jack-O-Lantern casting an eerie glow around the room. Laurie can't see who is lying on the bed from her position. Forward she moves and Annie is seen lying on the bed, her face a chalky white with a huge red gash across her throat. Laurie stares and a scream is let out at the top of her lungs, jumping back to the door. Bob is strung up to the light fixture on the ceiling, his eyes open and staring, causing Laurie to shrink back into a dark corner. Suddenly, a door next to her is slowly opened, and Lynda is revealed standing there, propped up by a chair, staring with glazed, dead eyes. The bedroom is backed out of by Laurie, her mouth open in speechless horror.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Laurie retrieves a key from her purse, locks the Doyle house, and walks into the street. The camera shifts to the dark Wallace house. Wind chills her as she moves faster up the sidewalk. Nearing the house, she knocks and rings the doorbell but hears nothing. Glancing back at the street, Laurie heads to the side of the house, moves through the breezeway to the back door, and steps inside, staring into the dark kitchen. Searching for the light, a dragging sound from upstairs stops suddenly. Laurie ascends the stairs, reaching a bedroom door with faint orange light. Inside, a Jack-O-Lantern glows eerily. Laurie sees Annie on the bed, her face pale with a gash on her throat, causing Laurie to scream. Bob hangs from the ceiling, eyes wide, making Laurie retreat into a corner. A door opens beside her, revealing Lynda, propped in a chair, staring with dead eyes. Laurie backs out, speechless with horror.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Laurie descends, takes a key from her purse, and heads to the window and front door, pocketing the Doyle house key. She locks it and walks into the street. The camera shifts to the ominous Wallace house. The wind tousles her hair as she shivers, passing Bob's car. She quickens her pace up the sidewalk, the house growing nearer. Laurie knocks, rings the doorbell, and waits. Hearing nothing, she thinks, glances at the street, and steps off the porch to the house's side, the camera following her. She goes through the breezeway to the back door, enters, and stands in the dark kitchen. Laurie searches for a light and listens. A dragging noise from upstairs halts. She ascends the staircase, reaching a bedroom door with faint light. Entering, she finds a Jack-O-Lantern glowing and sees Annie with a throat wound. Laurie screams, retreating. Bob hangs from the ceiling, eyes staring, making her recoil. A door opens next to her, revealing Lynda, propped by a chair, with dead eyes. Laurie retreats in silent horror.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Laurie makes her way back downstairs, pulling a key from within her purse with a sense of purpose, and approaches first the window and then the front door, carefully placing the key to the Doyle house securely into her pocket. With deliberate motions, she locks the Doyle house behind her and begins to walk away, stepping out onto the street. The camera shifts its focus toward the ominous and dark Wallace house, highlighting its foreboding presence. The wind is relentless as it whips through Laurieâ€™s clothes and hair, causing her to shiver from the biting chill that accompanies her down the street. Bob's car is parked solemnly on the side of the road. As realization dawns, she quickens her pace, moving briskly up the sidewalk, with the imposing facade of the house growing ever closer. The camera transitions to the front of the Wallace house just as Laurie ascends the front porch steps, where she knocks assertively on the door and rings the doorbell, ear tuned to any possible sounds emanating from within, waiting patiently for a brief moment. Laurie contemplates her next move and glances toward the street for any sign of life, then decisively steps off the porch, making her way to the side of the house with the camera following in her wake. She turns deliberately, walking through the narrow breezeway between the formidable house and its garage, reaching the back door, which she pulls open before stepping inside cautiously, momentarily frozen as she gazes into the black void of the dimly lit kitchen. Laurie gropes for the wall light, squinting into the unfathomable darkness. Suddenly, the noise of something being dragged across the floor upstairs echoes through the silence and comes to a sudden stop. Laurie approaches the base of the staircase, her heart pounding, and begins a slow ascent, the camera tracking each step. When she arrives at the top, she halts, noticing the bedroom door at the far end of the hall, glowing faintly with an orange hue around its edges. She advances toward the mysterious door, with the camera remaining vigilant by her side, and reaches it. The door creaks open, unveiling a Jack-O-Lantern that casts an eerie glow throughout the room. Someone lies on the bed, indistinct from Laurieâ€™s current vantage point. As she edges forward, horror seizes her: it is Annie on the bed, her face a ghostly, chalky white with a gruesome, large red gash across her throat. Paralyzed with shock, Laurie stares and lets out an ear-piercing scream, recoiling to the doorway. Overhead, suspended from the ceiling's light fixture is Bob, his eyes wide open and unseeing, forcing Laurie to shrink back into a nearby darkened corner. Abruptly, a door beside her creaks open slowly, revealing Lynda propped up by a chair, her eyes glazed over in deathâ€™s embrace. Laurie retreats out of the bedroom, her mouth frozen wide open in sheer, wordless horror.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Laurie descends the stairs with a determined air, reaching into the depths of her purse as she moves, extracting a key with assured intent. She approaches the window, her actions purposeful, and then proceeds to the front door. With a focused precision, she carefully places the key belonging to the Doyle house securely into her pocket. Her motions are deliberate as she locks the door of the Doyle house behind her, taking a moment before she steps out, exiting onto the street. The camera dramatically shifts its focus, highlighting the sinister and dark presence of the Wallace house in stark contrast, emphasizing its foreboding aura. The relentless wind gusts fiercely, sweeping through Laurieâ€™s attire and tousling her hair, sending chills through her as she continues down the street, shivering from the biting cold that accompanies her. A lone vehicle, Bob's car, sits parked somberly on the side of the road, its presence noted. As realization dawns within her, she hastens her pace, moving swiftly along the sidewalk, with the looming structure of the house drawing ever nearer. The camera transitions smoothly to the front view of the Wallace house, marking the moment Laurie climbs the front porch steps, whereupon she knocks firmly on the door and rings the doorbell, every sense attuned to any potential sounds from within, her wait brief yet tense. Contemplating her next possible course of action, Laurie glances back toward the street for any signs of life or movement, and then makes a decisive step off the porch, her movement direct as she heads toward the side of the imposing house, the camera trailing closely behind her. She pivots with intent, advancing through the narrow breezeway that lies between the formidable house and its garage, reaching for the back door. With cautious hesitation, she pulls it open and steps inside, pausing momentarily as she peers into the darkness of the dimly lit kitchen, a black void stretching before her. She fumbles slightly, groping for the wall light, her eyes narrowing against the seemingly impenetrable darkness. Without warning, a noise resonatesâ€”something being dragged across the floor above, its abrupt echo piercing the silence before stopping suddenly. Laurie makes her way to the base of the staircase, heart pounding rapidly in her chest, and begins the slow, steady ascent, with the camera capturing each deliberate step. Upon reaching the top, she comes to a halt, her eyes drawn to a bedroom door at the end of the hall, its edges outlined faintly by a mysterious orange glow. She starts advancing toward this enigmatic door, maintaining both the cameraâ€™s attention and her own vigilance. As she reaches it, the door opens with a creak, revealing a Jack-O-Lantern within, its eerie glow flooding the room. Someone is sprawled upon the bed, their identity indiscernible from Laurieâ€™s current vantage point. As she edges closer, horror grips her heart as recognition sets in: it is Annie who lies there, her face a ghastly shade of chalky white, marred by a gruesome, deep red gash across her throat. Laurie freezes in shock, horror-stricken, as she lets out a blood-curdling scream, recoiling immediately to the doorway. Suspended ominously from the ceiling's light fixture above, Bob hangs lifeless, his eyes vacant and unseeing, prompting Laurie to retreat into a nearby shadowed corner. Abruptly, a door beside her opens slowly and reveals Lynda, precariously propped up by a chair, her eyes glazed over, sealed in the embrace of death. Laurie backs away from the bedroom, her mouth agape in stunned, wordless horror, retreating in terror.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Laurie makes her way back downstairs, each step echoing in the quiet house, and once she reaches the bottom, she pauses momentarily to reach into her purse and retrieve a small, metallic key. She moves toward the window first, glancing outside briefly before shifting her path toward the front door, where she places the key to the Doyle house into her pocket for safekeeping. With a quick, practiced motion, she locks the Doyle house securely and steps outside, letting the door close behind her as she begins to walk away from the house and into the street. The camera's perspective shifts, capturing the formidable presence of the Wallace house, its darkened exterior conveying an ominous aura against the night. The wind howls through the street, making Laurie's clothes flutter and her hair whip about her face as she shivers involuntarily in the brisk air. As she continues her journey down the street, she spots Bob's car parked, its silent presence adding to the eerie atmosphere. Noticing how the distance shortens with each stride, Laurie quickens her pace on the sidewalk, her eyes fixed on the looming Wallace house now drawing nearer. The camera pans to the front of the house as Laurie approaches the front porch and ascends the steps, her footsteps soft but deliberate. She raises her hand to knock on the door, her knuckles tapping lightly against the wood, and follows this action by pressing the doorbell, the chime sounding muted in the stillness. She stands waiting, straining to catch any noise from within, her anticipation building during the brief pause. Thoughts flicker through her mind, prompting her to glance back toward the street, weighing her next move. Making a decision, Laurie steps off the porch, her feet carrying her toward the side of the house as the camera follows closely. She turns with purpose, navigating the passageway between the house and the garage, and upon reaching the back door, she grasps the handle, pulling it open to step cautiously inside. In the threshold of the dark kitchen, she halts, her eyes adjusting to the absence of light. Reaching out, she searches for the wall light, feeling its switch before flipping it, casting a dim glow into the darkness as she peers deeper into the room. A sudden, unsettling noise comes from upstairs, a sound resembling something being dragged abruptly ceasing, heightening her sense of unease. Gathering her resolve, Laurie moves toward the staircase, each step deliberate and deliberate, with the camera maintaining its focus on her determined ascent. As she arrives at the top, she halts momentarily, her gaze fixed on the bedroom door at the hallway's end, where faint orange light seeps through the edges, casting an otherworldly glow. She moves toward this door, each step accompanied by a growing trepidation, and upon reaching it, she hesitates for a fraction of a second. The door swings open slowly, the creaking hinges revealing the interior illuminated by the flickering, sinister glow of a Jack-O-Lantern. Within the room, a figure lies on the bed, obscured by shadow from Laurie's vantage point. She steps further inside, and as her eyes adjust, the tragic scene becomes clear: Annie lies on the bed, her skin a sickly, pallid hue, and an angry red gash slashes across her throat. Laurie is frozen for a heartbeat before terror seizes her, and she releases a piercing scream, her body jerking back in shock. Her retreat is halted by the ghastly sight above, where Bob hangs suspended from the light fixture, his lifeless eyes staring blankly down, prompting Laurie to recoil further into the darkness of a nearby corner. Suddenly, with a slow creak, a door beside her begins to open, revealing Lynda positioned stiffly, supported by a chair, her glazed eyes devoid of life. Laurie's horror mounts, her instinct propelling her backward out of the bedroom, her mouth agape in silent, overwhelming terror.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Laurie descends the stairs, retrieves a key from her purse, and secures the Doyle house before braving the chilly, wind-swept street. After passing Bob's car, she hastens toward the dark and foreboding Wallace house. Upon reaching the porch, she knocks and rings the doorbell but, hearing nothing, decides to investigate further. Moving through the breezeway to the back door, she enters the pitch-black kitchen, pausing to let her eyes adjust. Hearing a sound from upstairs, Laurie cautiously ascends the staircase and approaches a bedroom door emitting a faint orange glow. Inside, a Jack-O-Lantern illuminates the room where she discovers Annie's lifeless body with a gash across her throat. Horrified, Laurie screams and recoils, noticing Bob's body hanging from the ceiling. In shock, she backs into a corner as a nearby door creaks open, revealing Lynda propped up with lifeless eyes. Overcome with terror, Laurie retreats from the room, speechless and horrified.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Laurie comes back downstairs from the room where she had been storing her things, takes a key out of her purse, and steps to the window, then to the front door, putting the key to the Doyle house, famously known for its classic American architecture in this suburban neighborhood, in her pocket. She locks the Doyle house and walks away into the street that is eerily quiet at this late hour. The camera moves toward the Wallace house, which is dark and ominous, its reputation in the neighborhood as a once-lively home now overshadowed by its empty silence. The wind, often gusty during this season in this area known for its brisk autumns, whips her clothes and hair as she moves down the street, shivering in the chill wind. Bob's car, an old Chevrolet parked conspicuously alone on the street, sits on the street. She picks up her speed, moving up the sidewalk as the house looms closer, its shadow stretching across her path. The camera moves to the front of the Wallace house as Laurie walks up to the front porch, knocks on the door, and rings the doorbell, which once chimed cheerfully during happier times. She stands there, listening for any sound from inside, and waits a moment, her breath visible in the cold air. Laurie thinks and looks to the street, then steps off the porch and walks to the side of the house, the camera tracking with her, aware of the stillness that permeates the night. She turns and walks through the breezeway between the house and garage to the back door, pulls it open, and steps into the house, standing there for a moment staring into the blackness of the dark kitchen with its outdated appliances. Laurie searches for the wall light, remembering the switch location from previous visits, and looks again into the darkness. A sound from upstairs, like dragging across the floor, stops abruptly, resonating through the otherwise silent home. Laurie moves to the head of the staircase, which creaks underfoot, and slowly starts up, with the camera tracking her ascent. As she reaches the top and stops, she sees the bedroom door at the end of the hall with faint orange light around its edges, reminiscent of a softly flickering candle. She moves toward the door, the camera tracking with her, and reaches it. The door swings open to reveal a Jack-O-Lantern, carved with a simple yet menacing face, casting an eerie glow around the room. Someone is lying on the bed, but Laurie can't see them from her position. She moves forward and sees Annie, her close friend from school, on the bed, with her face a chalky white and a huge red gash across her throat. Laurie stares and screams at the top of her lungs, jumping back to the door. Strung up to the light fixture on the ceiling is Bob, eyes open and staring, causing Laurie to shrink back into a dark corner, her heart pounding in terror. Suddenly, a door next to her slowly opens to reveal Lynda, another of Laurie's friends, standing there, propped up by a chair, staring with glazed, dead eyes. Laurie backs out of the bedroom, her mouth open in speechless horror, unable to comprehend the scene before her.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Marty descends from the attic, pulls a spoon out of his briefcase, and hops to the mirror, then to the garden gate, placing the spoon to the Thompson barn in his shoe. He unlocks the Thompson barn and tiptoes away into the alley. The microphone glides toward the Johnson barn, which is bright and cheerful. The breeze tickles his hat and scarf as he dances down the alley, giggling in the warm breeze. Rick's bicycle lounges in the alley. He slows his pace, gliding down the path as the barn towers closer. The microphone drifts to the front of the Johnson barn as Marty skips up to the front stoop, taps on the gate, and presses the door knocker. He stands there, straining for any noise from within, and pauses a minute. Marty wonders and glances to the alley, then bounds off the stoop and skips to the rear of the barn, the microphone gliding with him. He pivots and skips through the alley between the barn and shed to the side gate, nudges it ajar, and skips into the barn, pausing for a minute peering into the brightness of the lit foyer. Marty hunts for the ceiling fan and peers again into the brightness. A noise from underneath, like tapping on the pipes, halts suddenly. Marty drifts to the toe of the ladder and briskly dances up, with the microphone capturing his ascent. As he reaches the peak and pauses, he notices the closet gate at the start of the corridor with soft green mist around its edges. He dances toward the gate, the microphone gliding with him, and approaches it. The gate flings wide to expose a Pumpkin Lantern emitting a soothing glow around the barn. Someone is resting on the hammock, but Marty can't glimpse them from his stance. He advances and notices Gail on the hammock, with her mask a rosy pink and a small blue stripe across her chin. Marty gazes and giggles at the peak of his voice, stumbling forward to the gate. Dangled up to the fan fixture on the ceiling is Rick, eyes shut and smiling, prompting Marty to stretch forward into a bright corner. Abruptly, a window beside him gently closes to expose Sandy lying there, supported by a table, watching with clear, bright eyes. Marty advances out of the closet, his lips curved in muted joy.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby cafÃ©, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Laurie retrieves a key from her purse, locks the Doyle house, and walks toward the dark, ominous Wallace house. She hurries past Bob's car, approaching the front porch, where she knocks and rings the doorbell. Hearing nothing, she moves to the house's side, enters through the back door, and pauses in the dark kitchen. After hearing a noise upstairs, she cautiously ascends the staircase, noticing a faint orange light around the bedroom door. Inside, a Jack-O-Lantern casts an eerie glow, revealing Annie on the bed with a red gash across her throat. Laurie screams, then sees Bob strung up from the ceiling, causing her to retreat in horror. A door opens to reveal Lynda, dead and propped up by a chair, prompting Laurie to back out of the room in speechless terror.

test_cases.name: Reverse Segments Order
test_cases.description: Laurie backs out of the bedroom her mouth open in speechless horror Suddenly a door next to her slowly opens to reveal Lynda standing there propped up by a chair staring with glazed dead eyes Strung up to the light fixture on the ceiling is Bob eyes open and staring causing Laurie to shrink back into a dark corner Laurie stares and screams at the top of her lungs jumping back to the door She moves forward and sees Annie on the bed with her face a chalky white and a huge red gash across her throat Someone is lying on the bed but Laurie cannot see them from her position The door swings open to reveal a JackOLantern casting an eerie glow around the room She moves toward the door the camera tracking with her and reaches it As she reaches the top and stops she sees the bedroom door at the end of the hall with faint orange light around its edges Laurie moves to the head of the staircase and slowly starts up with the camera tracking her ascent A sound from upstairs like dragging across the floor stops abruptly Laurie searches for the wall light and looks again into the darkness She turns and walks through the breezeway between the house and garage to the back door pulls it open and steps into the house standing there for a moment staring into the blackness of the dark kitchen Laurie thinks and looks to the street then steps off the porch and walks to the side of the house the camera tracking with her She stands there listening for any sound from inside and waits a moment The camera moves to the front of the Wallace house as Laurie walks up to the front porch knocks on the door and rings the doorbell She picks up her speed moving up the sidewalk as the house looms closer Bob's car sits on the street The wind whips her clothes and hair as she moves down the street shivering in the chill wind The camera moves toward the Wallace house which is dark and ominous She locks the Doyle house and walks away into the street Laurie comes back downstairs takes a key out of her purse and steps to the window then to the front door putting the key to the Doyle house in her pocket
